utterances: Yeah, maybe not.
But I think what he's comparing it to is all the other times he's seen Iraq, and that's what Iraqis compare it to as well.
But still, let's not exaggerate.
Baghdad has quite a lot of problems.
But for the first time in 16 years since Saddam Hussein was toppled, when you talk to most Iraqis, they say this is the safest they've felt in years.
Was he getting double takes from Iraqis in the markets and in the streets?
What was their reaction?
That was so interesting because, you know, I would have thought that he would, but either people ignored him, which kind of indicates they've moved on, or they wanted to take selfies with him.
There were a couple of people who yelled at him about the American presence.
But by far, most of the people were either bemused or seemed quite positive to see him walking around.
Listening to you, I mean, clearly, this is progress.
Clearly, this is something that couldn't have happened even a few years back but also feels so telling that it is still quite such a significant thing 16 years after the U.S.-led invasion for a U.S.
commander to be able to walk the streets of Baghdad.
Absolutely.

And one of the things it says too is that even though ISIS has been pushed out of the cities, Renforth and his Iraqi counterpart are very clear that does not, contrary to other conceptions, mean that ISIS is defeated.
You know, it takes a lot of effort by the Iraqi military and U.S.
advisers to keep it as safe as it has been.
So all of those thousands of people, they're also backed by the immense efforts that go into every Friday holiday, making sure that attacks don't happen.
They're very aware still that ISIS could still be out there, and they're not letting their guard down.
Thank you, Jane.
Thank you.
That's NPR's Jane Arraf reporting from Baghdad.
Good morning.
I'm Steve Inskeep.

Cleveland Cavaliers fans took this departure of LeBron James better than last time - they were furious when he left Cleveland years ago; his departure for LA met resignation - except for a man who tried to set a LeBron jersey on fire.
He laid the jersey on a paper beer case dumped in fuel from his weed eater, reached in with a match and set himself on fire.
The New York Post says he wasn't seriously hurt, but the video looks painful.
It's MORNING EDITION.
Presidential candidates are everywhere in New Hampshire these days.
But reporter Shannon Mullen has found one town that has never been visited by a presidential hopeful.
Marlow, New Hampshire, is a picture-postcard town with a little pond, the white church steeple and the Odd Fellow's Hall.
Just under 800 people lived here.
The last presidential candidate who was scheduled to pass through Marlow was William Taft on October 12, 1912.
The whole town went out to meet him, says resident Charlie Strickland(ph).
He was coming down from Newport going to Keene, and that he got up here to Marlow Junction and he took the wrong road there and got lost.
So Taft never showed.
A few years later, in 1920, New Hampshire's primary won it's first-in-the-nation spot.
But so far, the campaign trail has yet to bring a presidential candidate through Marlow.
I think they have too many campaign managers.
They have too many aides.
I think the aides would never allow them to do it.
Marlow resident Mary Blanc volunteered for Bill Clinton's first New Hampshire campaign, helping out with events in bigger towns.
She says even though presidential candidates come to the state for its retail politics, they limit appearances in places like Marlow.
They were not going to show here.
It would be quaint and sweet, but I'm not sure how much bang for their buck they would get.
I think it's probably almost impossible for them to get to all the towns, however, it would have been nice if, since 1920, somebody has showed up at least once.
(Soundbite of laughter)
That's Joe Fewer, a former state representative and a registered Republican.
I would like to see McCain come here.
Why?
Because at this point I'm leaning toward him and I would like to meet him one-on-one in my hometown.
I'm Peter Eisenstatter.
I'm a registered Democrat.
I would have liked to have seen at least one candidate come through here, yes.
And I think that candidate would probably gotten some more credit for having bothered to come to a place like this.
How deep is he willing to dig into the countryside to find out how good a candidate he or she might be.
I'm Janet Bells and I am a registered Democrat.
I really would love to see Barack Obama come here.
Tremendously symbolic moment.
I think you're absolutely right that the first black man to be really a front-running candidate for president in the United States should come to Marlow, New Hampshire.
These Marlow residents say they're ready for a visit from any candidate who's brave enough to take their questions.
The only exception is Charlie Strickland, who says he hasn't like the presidential pickings for half a century.
The last one I voted for I liked was Eisenhower.
The rest of them are all take the lesser of the evils.
(Soundbite of laughter)
For any 2008 contenders interested in visiting Marlow, residents advise against coming here during black fly season.
And they warn that campaign staffers might not get cell phone reception here.
But the hospitality is excellent.
There'll be baked good, and Mary Blanc says the Odd Fellows might even loan out their meeting hall for an event.
All the town asks is for the candidates to show up this time.
For NPR News, I'm Shannon Mullen.
It's election time in Iraq.
Iraqis go to the polls on Saturday, the first parliamentary elections since ISIS took over a third of the country in 2014 and held it for years.
Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi is running for re-election largely based on success at eventually defeating that group.
NPR's Jane Arraf reports from a nation that has undergone a lot of change since the last election.
This is a campaign rally for Prime Minister Haider Haider al-Abadi.
It's in an overwhelmingly Shiite area of Baghdad, Sadr City.
Abadi is also Shiite like every prime minister since Saddam Hussein was toppled.
It still matters a lot in Iraqi politics whether you're Shiite or Sunni or Kurdish or Arab.
But increasingly, security and sectarianism are not the first things on people's minds.
Eight years ago, Iraq was emerging from civil war.
Four years ago, there were suicide car bombs at campaign rallies in this neighborhood.
And now...
(CHEERING)
...They've just released a flock of doves.
They're flying in circles over the stadium as blue balloons go up in the air.
I'm surrounded by young guys wearing blue T-shirts with Abadi's logo on them.
(Chanting in foreign language).
People in the crowd didn't seem to care that Abadi's microphone didn't work.
A lot of them were bussed in from other poor neighborhoods, like Um Fatma.
She says she was expecting food or money, but all she got was a campaign hat.
(Speaking Arabic).
If he does something for me, I'll vote for him - if he doesn't, I won't.
I can't pay the rent.
And I swear to God, I have no food left in the house to feed the children."" Abadi is a U.K.-educated engineer, considered moderate.
His other big message, like this one at a rally in the south of Iraq, is all about the economy.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
(Through interpreter) Today we need unity and integrity to achieve our second victory, which is reconstruction, creating jobs and providing services.
It is not an easy task.
It will take sacrifices.
But believe me, with cooperation and unity and working together, we can achieve miracles.
Working together would be a kind of miracle in itself.
In this election, there are 27 coalitions with 143 different parties running.
They range from Islamic religious parties to communists.
Abadi's main rival is a paramilitary commander with ties to Iran.
Hadi al-Amiri's support comes from a divisive source - the former militias now called Popular Mobilization Forces.
They're feared by some Iraqis, but as Amiri points out in an interview with NPR, they're also credited with stopping ISIS forces from reaching Baghdad.
(Through interpreter) Of course the love of the people for the Popular Mobilization Forces is huge.
People appreciate the sacrifices by the Popular Mobilization members to preserve and protect Iraq.
Here's another big factor in these elections - a lot of these voters are young.
More than 3 million Iraqis have turned 18 since the last elections, and they're eligible to vote for the first time.
Now they have more security, they're looking for taste of prosperity.
Near the Friday book market on al-Mutanabbi Street, I run into one of the youngest candidates.
Ali Mohammad Nouri (ph) turned 30 just two days before the deadline to register.
(Through interpreter) I want to defend the rights of the deprived youth and their wasted college degrees.
I hope this election will be based on qualifications and not quotas.
Sajad Jiyad, head of the Al-Bayan Center, a Baghdad think tank, says these elections mark a new era.

I think the most important thing for Iraqis is they want to see the state moving on from war, and that means a focus on services, a focus on job creation, paying attention to the 60 percent of Iraq's population who are now under 30 years old.
Those people, he says, care about the future and not Iraq's troubled sectarian past.
Jane Arraf, NPR News, Baghdad.
In the 1960's, Eldridge Cleaver became a black revolutionary legend.
He came to national prominence with the book Soul on Ice, a series of essays he wrote from prison.
The book, which focused on racism and prejudice, became a best-seller.
After his release in 1966, Cleaver joined the Black Panther party, where he met his wife Kathleen.
The two became something of a revolutionary celebrity couple.
Eldridge died in 1998.
Kathleen has compiled many of her late ex-husband's unpublished writings into a new book called Target Zero.
Before we talked about the book, I asked if it was ever difficult to deal with Cleaver's overpowering personality.
